title: Brussels’ mayors to consider ban on e-scooter in drug dealing hotspots
first_lines: Municipalities in Brussels municipalities are considering measures that would restrict the use of e-scooters in areas that are affected by drug dealing. The exact nature and extent of the measures have yet to be finalised.
content: The Brussels regional news platform reports that on Thursday the Chair of the Conference of Brussels Mayors Benoît Cerexhe (Francophone centrist) said that the Brussels-Capital Region’s 19 Mayors are expected to decide next Wednesday on whether a working party should be set up to draw up measures to limit the use of e-scooters in drug crime hotspots. Several weeks ago, Brussels’ Chief Prosecutor Julien Moinil asked the Conference of Mayors to identify the users of shared e-scooters in drug crime hotspots. Mr Moinil says that the scooters are used both by dealers and hitmen that work for drug gangs. Earlier this week, the Chief Prosecutor sent a letter to Mr Cerexhe highlighting the growing number of road traffic accidents involving shared e-scooters.

Mr Cerexhe says that while he favours measures to more effectively identify users of the scooters, he does not favour a ban on their uses in certain areas at certain times (for example in the evening and/or at night).

However, in an interview with the Francophone region broadcaster BX1, the Francophone socialist mayor of Saint-Gillis Jean Spinette (PS), expressed stronger support for a ban on shared scooters in hotspots. However, Mr Spinette, whose municipality contains several drug hotspots, is not in favour of restrictions on the use of private scooters. Although he does think that they should be registered.

The Brussels regional MP Sofia Bennani (Francophone centrist) is in favour of a ban on the use of e-scooters between 10pm and 5am in municipalities that are worst affected by drug crime. These are the municipalities of Anderlecht, Schaarbeek, Sint-Gillis, Vorst and Sint-Jans-Molenbeek. She warns that limitting an e-scooter ban to hotspots could result in simply moving the problem on to somewhere else. Ms Bennani advocates an exemption for night-shift workers who rely on scooters to get to work.

title: National Bank warns of “worrying outlook” for public debt
first_lines: Once again, the National Bank of Belgium has expressed concern about the state of Belgium's public finances. Although France, Italy, Japan and the US have far higher debt ratios than Belgium, the National Bank warns that Belgium's debt position is as fragile as theirs.
content: Belgium’s public debt currently stands at around 104% of GDP. This compares with 113% % in France, 135% in Italy, 122% the United States and a huge 236% in Japan. The National Bank warns however that focusing solely on headline figures can obscure deeper structural weaknesses. It argues that debt sustainability depends not only on the current level of debt, but also on future borrowing needs, fiscal trends and general economic dynamics.

In Belgium's case, short-term risks remain limited. However, the National Bank of Belgium has one major concern: the government's gross financing requirement. This amounts to around 20% of GDP each year. On the hand Belgium’s positive net foreign investment position offers some resilience, as domestic savings could help to absorb any funding shocks. Belgian savers demonstrated this resilience in 2011, when they purchased bonds after foreign investors pulled back from Belgian debt.

Looking further ahead, the National Bank describes the projected increase in Belgium’s public debt as “worrying”. It cites persistent budget deficits, mounting interest costs, and expenditure related to an ageing population.

The National Bank concludes that while our economy is not facing an immediate crisis, a sudden shift in market sentiment could quickly turn liquidity pressures into solvency risks. This would turn today's slow-burning debt dynamics into tomorrow's financial emergency.

title: Protest against UAE’s alleged complicity in the violence in Sudan
first_lines: Several hundred people have held a demonstration outside the Embassy of the United Arab Emirates in Brussels. They were protesting against what they see as the UAE’s complicity in the violence committed by the paramilitary group Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in Sudan. The protesters say that the United Arab Emirates supports RSF due to economic interests.
content: The Sudanese government says that the paramilitary group Rapid Support Forces is supported by Dubai. The United Arab Emirates strongly deny this. However, several international reports on the situation in Sudan state that the UAE has exported modern drones, heavy duty machine guns, artillery, mortars and munitions to paramilitaries in Sudan. They have done so in exchange for Sudanese gold that is found in the south of the country in areas controlled by RSF.
The organisers of the demonstration say that around 600 people took part. They are demanding an economic boycott against the United Arab Emirates.

One demonstrator told journalists that "The UAE is compliant in the genocide that is taking place in Sudan”. The demonstrator wished to remain anonymous due to fears for the safety of his family that is currently still in living in Sudan.

The protesters also denounced what they describe as the “hypocritical attitude” of Belgium and the European Union. According to the protesters, Belgian weapons are being supplied to RSF via the United Arab Emirates. They want Belgium and Europe to issue a clear condemnation of the violence.

"The EU must impose a total embargo on the United Arab Emirates and South Sudan” the anonymous activist and organiser of the demonstration said. “The export of all services and goods to the United Arab Emirates and Sudan must be stopped.”

The demonstrators add that the European Union must behave as a responsible player and not perpetuate “this proxy war”. The EU must “Take a stand and take responsibility. Belgium must stop all arms deliveries to countries that supply RSF.”

title: Belgium “at risk” from migration pressure says European Commission
first_lines: The European Commission’s 2025 European Annual Asylum and Migration Report has classified Belgium as a “risk country” with regard migration pressure.  11 other EU countries, including Germany, France, Ireland, the Netherlands and Poland are also considered by the Commission to considered to face a potential migration pressure risk.
content: The report covers the period from July 2024 to June 2025. It notes a “steady improvement” in migration trends, including a 35% fall in illegal border crossings. However, it also highlights ongoing challenges such as arrival of undocumented migrants and the reception of refugees from Ukraine.

The 27 EU member states were ranked according to factors such as the number of migrants and asylum applications, GDP and population size. Belgium is among twelve EU member states identified as facing a potential risk of migration pressure, whereby reception systems are strained or migration has been or is being used as a political tool. The latter has been seen previously in Poland.
“At risk” countries may qualify for financial support through the EU’s “toolbox” that was set up as part of the Migration Pact. The Migration Pact will take effect in June.

Meanwhile, countries, such as Cyprius, Greece, Italy and Spain that are experiencing the highest levels of migration pressure will be able to rely on help through the EU’s solidarity mechanism, whereby other member states take in some of their asylum seekers.

However, several northern countries, including the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany, Sweden and Finland, have said that they will only agree to a relocation system once the EU’s Dublin Regulation on migration is more strictly applied.

title: Mars to close its rice packaging factory at Olen in Antwerp Province
first_lines: Mars Belgium has announced plans to close its factory in Olen. The company announced the closure in a press statement released earlier on Wednesday. Around 80 jobs are under threat as a result of the closure announcement. Mars Belgium says that economic challenges including falling production volumes and rising costs are forcing it to close the factory.
content: Mars Belgium says that the factors listed above have resulted in its Olen site being underutilised which in turn has had a significant impact on efficiency. The factory is due to close at the end of next year.
The Olen factory has been open for around 50 years and was formally part of Master Foods. It produces and packages rice sold under the Ben’s Original brand that was previously called ‘Uncle Ben’s’.

Mars Belgium said in its press statement that it had informed employees and their trade union representatives of its intentions.  The company stresses that its priority now is to engage in a “meaningful and transparent information and consultation process” and to “support employees throughout this period with care and respect.”
If the closure goes ahead Mars, will outsource the production of Ben’s Original dry rice products for the European market.

title: Almost half of all households in Brussels are made up of 1 person
first_lines: Figures published by the federal statistics bureau Statbel reveal that almost half of all households in the Brussels-Capital Region are single-person households. Statbel published the figure to mark Singles Day that like Armistice Day takes place on 11 November.
content: Singles’ Day is the day on which single people the world over celebrate the fact that they are single. Singles' Day has been celebrated in China on 11 November since the 1990s.

In more recent years it has gradually become popular in Europe too. To mark Singles Day the federal statistics bureau Statbel published figures on the number of single-person households in Belgium. According to Statbel’s figures 1.8 million people in Belgium are living alone. This constitutes 36.3% of all the country’s households.

In the Brussels-Capital Region the percentage is higher still with 47.1% of all households consisting of one person. In Wallonia this is 37.7%, while Flanders has the lowest percentage of single-person households (33.4%).
It is forecast that by 2060 more than half of all households in Belgium will be single person households.

title: Fivefold increase in the number of average-speed cameras in Flanders since 2023
first_lines: The number of average-speed cameras on Flemish roads has risen sharply during the past 2 years. In 2023 there were 246 of the cameras in Flanders. Now there are 1,233. The figures come from the Federal Interior Minister Bernard Quantin (Francophone liberal). They highlight the Flemish regional authorities’ growing investment in traffic enforcement.
content: Belgium’s other 2 regions have far fewer average speed cameras installed alongside their roads. According to figures published in the dailies ‘Het Nieuwsblad’ and ‘Gazet van Antwerpen’, Wallonia has 97 of the cameras, while the Brussels-Capital Region has 12.
On average, there are now four average-speed cameras in each of Flanders’ 285 municipalities. However, Mr Quintin has not confirmed whether all 1,233 cameras in Flanders are currently operational.

The road traffic safety expert Professor Johan De Mol of Ghent University (UGent) told the press agency Belga that average speed camera systems are “valuable tools for road safety”. However, this is only the case if they are installed correctly.
“Too many are positioned just after a speed limit drops, for example from 70 to 50km/h. That’s a trap for drivers”, Professor De Mol said.

The debate concerning average-speed cameras is not new. Earlier this year, Flemish Transport Minister Annick De Ridder (nationalist) cancelled the installation of 70 new camera systems. This prompted criticism from researchers that said the number of serious accidents had fallen by 56% where average-speed camera systems had been put in place.

Meanwhile, opposition parties have also accused the government of using motorists as “cash cows”. Nevertheless, experts stress that properly designed and fairly deployed cameras are crucial for road safety.

title: 17-year-olds invited to do voluntary military service
first_lines: From today (Wednesday 12 November) all 17-year-olds in Belgium will receive a letter calling on them to sign up for a year’s voluntary military service in the Belgian armed forces. The Flemish Youth Council is critical of the tone of the letter and says that if a job advertisement  placed on the Flemish Employment Service’s (VDAB) website was written in the same style, there wouldn’t be many applicants for the job. Nevertheless, the Belgian military hopes that a least 1,500 young people will sign up.
content: “Congratulations! Next year you will turn 18. This is an important milestone and a time when you will make choices for your future. The Ministry of Defence is offering you a unique opportunity, a voluntary Military Service Year”

This is how the letter that was sent to around 130,000 17-year-olds in Belgium at the end of last week begins. The aim of the letter is to encourage them to sign up for a year with the armed services. In return they will be given a salary of at 2,000 euro/month, luncheon vouchers, their medical costs will be refunded and they will be able to travel free of charge on public transport to and from work.

After an intensive 10-week basic training course, followed by a specific training course lasting 1 to 3 weeks (depending on the position), they will start work at a military barracks, where they will “take part in exercises and operations”.

The Defence Ministry says that the military service year "is a unique opportunity to develop both personally and professionally, make friends for life and gain work experience”. What's more, “you will be actively contributing to the future of our country, in an international context in which we must be prepared and ready to act."

Anna Roos of the Flemish Youth Council believes that the latter will certainly appeal to young people. She is the chair of the Flemish Youth Council and has noticed how young people are concerned about military conflicts around the world. “Sudan, Ukraine, Gaza. Every day, social media shows horrific images of war. You can't ignore it. The current issue of drones is also a cause for concern”, she told VRT Radio 1’s morning news and current affairs programme ‘De Ochtend’.

“In the past, defence was a niche issue. But now it has such an important impact on so many people in the world and perhaps soon also on our own security as well. We see defence as a form of collectieve insurance.”

Nevertheless, Ms Roos is not really certain that the letter will encourage youngsters to join up. “Although experts on young people were consulted, the letter is rather dryly worded. It does not contain much information. If this had been a vacancy on the VDAB website, not many people would have applied. A year of your life is a long time, especially when you are 18”.

Those that are interested will be given more information during info sessions that will take place between 22 November and 7 December. Attendance at once of the sessions is compulsory for anyone that wishes to do the military service. "There is only session per province, while 149,000 letters have been send. I am curious about the practicalities of this."

Anna Roos understands why the Ministry of Defence is focusing on 17-year-olds. “I am 21 and a student, so a year of military service is no longer an option for me. Many 18 to 26-year-olds have already made important choices in their lives. I think becoming a reservist is more appealing to us.”

The Ministry of Defence expects around 1,500 young people to apply to do a military service year. Of these, 500 will ultimately be able to start, this represents 0.38% of all the young people that hab been received a letter. 375 will do their military service in the army, 75 in the air force and 50 in the navy.

title: Northern Lights seen in the skies above Flanders
first_lines: On Tuesday night the Northern Lights were visible in some parts of the north of the country. It is hoped that they will be visible again tonight.
content: Social media has been awash with photography of the (pink) Northern Lights. Although most of the photos we came across were taken in the Netherlands, the Flemish weather spotter Bart Medaer was also able to photograph the Northern Lights in the north of Antwerp Province.

On Tuesday night the Northern Lights were pink in colour. The colour of the Northern Lights depends on how deep the particles charged by what is called a “solar blast” penetrate the earth’s atmosphere.

We may get another chance to see the Northern Lights late this evening or overnight. They may well be more intense than was the case last night. Christine Verbeke of Leuven University (KU Leuven) VRT News that “A new, even faster solar storm is approaching Earth. What's more, the Earth's magnetic field is still recovering from the previous storm. This means that the impact is likely to be even greater. I am hopeful that the northern lights will be more intense than last night, but of course this remains a prediction, just like the weather forecast.”
If you don't want to miss the Northern Lights, you should look north late tonight or tonight, low on the horizon and in a dark place.
There is good news from the VRT’s weatherman Bram Verbruggen as he says that “The weather will be clear tonight.”

It started with a large explosion on the sun a few days ago. The explosion sent solar storms towards Earth. Last night, the first of these storms reached our planet. The charged particles carried by the storms collide with our atmosphere and it is this that creates the Northern Lights.

Normally, the Northern Lights can only be seen in areas such as the north of Scotland, Scandinavia, etc. However, in recent years they have also been observed several times in Belgium. This comes about where there is a peak in solar storms.

Just like on Earth, there are seasons on the Sun, during which the Sun becomes more or less active. Every 11 years, activity on the Sun peaks, and that is currently in full swing. If you want to spot the Northern Lights, it is best not to wait too long, because according to space weather expert Christine Verbeke, the peak has just passed.

title: Moscow warns that "Belgium risks liability if frozen Russian assets are used”
first_lines: Russia has warned Belgium against seizing frozen Russian assets held by Euroclear in Brussels. The European Commission wants to use the frozen Russian cash for a new loan to Ukraine. Only once the war is over, sanctions are lifted and Russia pays Ukraine compensation for the damage inflected by the war would Ukraine repay the loan to the EU.
content: Belgium has so far been reluctant to release the money. The Belgian Prime Minister Bart De Wever (Flemish nationalist) says that he wants firmer guarantees from the rest of the European Union that the potential legal risks will be shared.

Now Moscow is has issued a warning to Belgium not to seize the money. “Belgium will face a serious liability issue if Russian assets are seized”, the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) told the Russian state press agency Tass.

“EU countries are teetering on the brink of social and economic crisis and their coffers are empty. They now want to pay for Ukrainian grain with stolen Russian assets”, SVR says. “Belgium that manages the 'joint fund', is resisting the plan because it fears it will be held liable. That is the right way to think, because they will certainly be held liable.’”

title: Unemployment in Brussels rises to 15.3%
first_lines: According to the latest figures from the Brussels regional employment service Actiris 96,161 people in the capital were registered as jobseekers at the end of last month. This is a rise of 4% on the figures from the end of October last year. The rise in the number of jobseekers is greatest among those with high levels of academic attainment.
content: In October 2025 there were more people resistering with Actiris (11,546) than there were people living in the Brussels-Capital Region that were on the regional employment services books and found new jobs (10,078).
This is a net increase of also 1,500 in the number of jobseekers in Brussels. Almost half (48%) of those registered with Actiris are women, just over half (52%) are men.
The increase is evident in almost all age groups. The year-on-year increase was greatest among those younger than 25 (+6.1%) and those aged between 25 and 49 (+4.6%).

A growing number of well-qualified people are also seeking work. The number of people with high levels of academic attainment that are registered as jobseekers with Actiris has increased by more than 10% during the past year. Meanwhile, the number of people that have been without work for more than 2 years has also increased.

title: Federal Finance Minister warns of the economic consequences of failing to make progress on the budget
first_lines: Speaking on Thursday, the Federal Finance Minister Vincent Van Peteghem (Flemish Christian democrat) warned that failing to make decisive progress in the federal budget talks will derail economic growth and stall investment. Speaking in the Federal Parliament, Mr Van Peterghem said that the ongoing budget negotiations are “complex and far-reaching” and stressed that “what Europe demands of us will be the bare minimum”.
content: As the Belgian Prime Minister Bart De Wever (Flemish nationalist) was attending a European Summit, it was Mr Van Petergem that answered MPs questions about the stalled budget negotiations. The Finance Minister said that the current budgetary efforts are weighed down by "an inheritance for which we all share responsibility". He also said that interest payments on public debt could account for more as much as 40% within a few years.
Mr Van Peteghem told MPs that the governments ultimate aim is “clear and not up for debate". He also warned that meeting the EU's expenditure target would take time.

“We must do what is necessary, not what is easy,” Taking difficult decisions now will prevent an erosion of purchasing power and prosperity later, the Finance Minister said. If no action is taken Belgium risks becoming “a society where everyone is left to fend for themselves”.

title: Bruges police use speed test bench to check mopeds and e-scooters
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: Bruges police have had a busy night. During a major check on two-wheel traffic half of all drivers checked, were found to be in violation in some way or other. People on mopeds and bikes were either speeding, had no lights or were ignoring traffic signs. One moped was even able to do 116 kilometres per hour on a test bench.
content: ‘The checks were focused on mopeds, fat bikes, e-scooters, speed pedelecs and regular bicycles. But motorists who committed offences were also pulled over,’ explains Lien Depoorter of the Bruges police.

‘We checked 156 drivers. Half of them were fine and received a gadget from our prevention team. The other half were caught committing all kinds of offences, connected to lighting, position on the road, ignoring traffic signs or traffic lights.’

The police were also on the lookout for souped-up mopeds. In Bruges they used a new test bench for the first time. It allows the speed of different types of vehicles to be measured, including fat bikes and e-scooters. ‘One moped reached a speed of 116 kilometres per hour on the test bench. That moped was confiscated and also declared forfeited. This means that the owner will never get their moped back,’ explains Depoorter.

"A total of 15 souped-up mopeds were confiscated, 12 people were fined for ignoring traffic signs, 11 for using a smartphone while cycling or riding a scooter, and 48 for not having bicycle lights. Cyclists not holding their handlebars were also fined. 23 motorists were fined for overtaking a cyclist in a bicycle zone. The Bruges bicycle zone was expanded significantly last 1 October.

‘We have noticed that many people are still breaking the rules, despite intensive prevention campaigns. Such large-scale checks remain necessary, in addition to daily detection efforts,’ concludes Depoorter.

title: A secret sale at your local Kruidvat drugstore? Fraudsters spread fake advertisement via Facebook
first_lines: Advertisements are doing the rounds on Facebook promoting a special offer it is claimed that some employees of the Kruidvat drugstore chain are aware of. A set of personal beauty products is offered for just a few euro in return for completing a short survey. VRT News’ Fact Check Team found that the ads and the profiles that share them are fake.
content: A large gift set containing skincare products for just 2 euros? It seems too good to be true and of course it isn’t. Several advertisements that appear on Facebook claim that the drugstore chain Kruidvat has a secret that only a few people know about.

Kruidvat is said to be selling off old stock at bargain prices. If the ads are to be believed, you can buy a Sol de Janeiro gift set for just 2 euros after completing a short survey. Unfortunately, this it's nothing more than a scam.

The various advertisements consistently tell a similar story. Those that post them claim to have learned about the special offer through a sister who works at Kruidvat or an acquaintance recently laid off by the retailer. Facebook's Ad Library shows that the ads have been viewed over a million times in Belgium.

Each post is followed by a comment with a link leading to a website containing the supposed Kruidvat survey. Once completed, you can click through to a form where you're asked for payment and your personal details.

Although you might never receive the box containing skincare products. As you have entered your bank details, the scammers will be able to withdraw money from your account. They can also use your personal data for phishing purpose or to sell it on to others.

The profiles behind the ads are made by people posing as Belgians with typically Belgian names. However, a glance at the profiles quickly reveals that they were recently created and have no followers or friends. They have only a handful of photos, and there are no interactions on photos that are unrelated to the scam.
Using the Pimeyes tool, VRT Fact Check discovered that the photo of Katrien De Smet that was used by the scammers is that a real person from the Netherlands, albeit someone with a different name.

Not only the advertisements but also the people that respond so enthusiastically to the ads are fake. Photos supposedly of parcels of skincare products that have just arrived at someone’s home are taken to enhance credibility.

In addition to this, the profiles of the people posting the comments abouts the ads are also fake again. The scammers clearly went out of their way to make the profiles appear genuine. The hometown, workplace, and relationship status are all filled in. However, VRT Fack Check used Pimeyes to check the photographs on the profiles that it investigated and found that they appeared elsewhere on the social media accounts of people with a completely different name.

Kruidvat’s spokesperson Sander Khouw told the VRT that fake advertisements promoting fake special offers often appear on social media. "We do our utmost to take action where possible and/or to inform consumers." Mr Khouw stresses that advertisements VRT Fact Check investigated are not part of a Kruidvat advertising campaign.
Kruidvat isn't the only company to fall prey to fake ads. The namers of several other retail companies, such as Decathlon, MediaMarkt, and The North Face, have also been used by scammers.

: Is the product you can win through the ad normally worth a lot of money, but now you're only being asked to pay a few euro? Beware! If something sounds too good to be true, it more often than not isn’t.
: If the page has few followers or photos, it's best not to trust it. Check the supposed vendor’s official page to see if you can find the promotional offer there.
: After clicking on a link for a deal, first check the web address at the top of your screen. If it looks strange and doesn't resemble an official brand website, don't proceed.
Contact your bank to have the scammers stop any ongoing and future transactions.

title: ‘Repetition works’: 1 Russian fake news story about Zelensky’s wealth every month since invasion of Ukraine
author: Ellen Debackere
first_lines: A villa, a sports car, expensive jewellery: in the 40 months since Russia invaded Ukraine, there have been at least as many fake news campaigns about the private spending of president Volodymyr Zelensky. Many of these come from or were spread by pro-Russia Telegram channels. Their aim? To undermine support for aid to Ukraine.
content: Since the start of the war in Ukraine, at least 40 fake news campaigns have been launched, reporting on the alleged expenses of Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky, primarily by pro-Russian channels.

The articles, alleging luxury purchases such as a villa or a sports car by Zelensky or his wife, have been debunked every time. They appear to be intended to undermine support for aid to Ukraine in its fight against Russia.
VRT NWS Russia expert Marijn Trio: “The Russians are very good at capitalising on the algorithms of social media and they know which sensitive topics they can use to sow division.”
Volodymyr Zelensky’s wife did not buy a “€4 million Bugatti” in Paris and the president
. But that’s what many posts on social media would have us believe: that Zelensky is taking Western money meant for the defence of his country and spending it on luxuries.
In the 40 months since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, our journalists have counted at least 40 fake news stories about the president’s supposed spending – one fabricated story for every month.
What are they saying? There have been false claims about Zelensky’s purchase of villas around the world, as well as fake reports about
Sometimes the stories originate on pro-Russian Telegram channels, from where they are spread further.
One example is the rumour about Zelensky buying a villa in Florida:
and was subsequently picked up by
that spreads fake news about Ukraine, among other things, via simulated websites.
Other articles are first published on obscure websites set up for the sole purpose of spreading a particular falsehood. That was the case, for example, in the story alleging Zelensky had
. Messages are then picked up and spread further by channels with a wider reach, such as the X accounts of Russian embassies or pro-Russian influencers.
The fake story about Zelensky’s wife buying a sports car in France is a perfect example of how Russian disinformation works and spreads online.

A fake story – “Olena Zelenska buys a Bugatti in Paris” – is attached to a real event: the couple’s visit to France. A news website is created – in this case, a site called Vérité Cachée, or Hidden Truth – for the sole purpose of writing an article about it. This article is then used as a source by Russian media and pro-Russian accounts on social media to spread the fake story.
The spate of fabrications also brings to mind allegations of tax evasion by Zelensky. He surfaced a few years ago in
: leaked documents from companies that had parked offshore funds. So how rich is he, really?
Estimates on his wealth vary. The Celebrity Net Worth website
, as of March this year. According to
, his wealth in 2022 stood at $20 million.
Following the Maidan Revolution in 2014, Ukraine introduced a
in which public figures including MPs are required to submit a declaration of their assets each year. The
– from March this year – shows that
before the Russian invasion of February 2022. The list of assets includes several apartments in Ukraine.

Why are pro-Russian factions going to so much effort to create all these fake stories? They have one major goal: to cast doubt on support to Ukraine and make people ask if aid money is getting to where it should.

According to VRT NWS Russia expert Marijn Trio, the Russians are trying to undermine Zelensky’s legitimacy. The undertone of each of the stories is: “This is what’s happening with the aid to Ukraine. It’s not going to the Ukrainian people or to the army, but to the wallets of the Ukrainian elite.”

And that message cuts through, because “repetition works”, he says. People see the stories and are subconsciously influenced, especially if there’s a continuous stream of them. Trio: “People mention it to me. They see stories like this and ask themselves if something isn’t right.”
Fake news works best if it’s based on a grain of truth. In this case, the false stories recall
. “But Zelensky was elected precisely on a promise to address this corruption,” says Trio. “So it’s extra hurtful for him to be accused of corruption.

“The Russians are very good at capitalising on the algorithms of social media and they know which sensitive topics they can use to sow division,” he says. “It’s important that people know the ways in which this happens so they can be alert to it.”

title: Brooch seized from Napoleon at Waterloo auctioned for €3.7 million
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: A diamond-encrusted brooch belonging to French emperor Napoleon, which was captured by the Prussian army at Waterloo (Walloon Brabant – Belgium), has been auctioned in Geneva (Switzerland) for a record €3.79 million, according to auction house Sotheby's. The auctioneers had initially estimated the sale price at between €130,000 and €220,000.
content: The brooch was among the personal belongings that the emperor had to leave behind during his flight from Waterloo, outside Brussels, when he attempted to escape from British and Prussian soldiers. It was this famous battle that ultimately sealed his downfall.

The round piece of jewellery, with a diameter of approximately 45 mm, includes a large oval diamond weighing 13.04 carats in the centre. This central diamond is surrounded by almost 100 other diamonds in various shapes and sizes, arranged in two concentric rows.

This unique piece was made for Napoleon around 1810, ‘probably to adorn his bicorne hat on special occasions,’ the auction house notes. The jewel was then presented, along with other items, to the Prussian King Frederick William III on 21 June 1815, just three days after the Battle of Waterloo, as a war trophy.

title: Russia is attempting to discredit the EU by disseminating fake news on a massive scale: VRT NEWS has mapped dozens of stories and explains how to recognise them!
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: On social media, the European Union (EU) is regularly portrayed as a dictatorship that wants to interfere in every aspect of our lives. Criticism is fine, but there are also many fake stories to influence us, mainly spread by pro-Russian sources. Our editorial team has selected 60 of these fake stories. How can you recognise them?
content: False reports are circulating online that portray the EU as a dictatorial bloc that is removing all power from the member states. Reports have claimed that the EU is forcing farms in Bulgaria to employ a certain number of LGBTI+ people, that Christmas is to be abolished, and that gel nails are to be banned.

Legitimate criticism of the EU and its functioning this is not. These are false claims. There is no evidence whatsoever for dozens of claims that VRT News's editorial team discovered through fact-checking. This fake news is usually widely disseminated by pro-Russian accounts with the aim of undermining the EU's image and influencing elections. You can recognise these false claims by using a number of tips.
‘The
only to use straw-based toilet paper’ or ‘

allows the EU to arrest critical journalists’. It is not difficult to find messages on social media that portray the EU as a dictatorship that controls the lives of its citizens with oppressive legislation.

We see these kinds of messages popping up in almost all EU member states. Even in non-EU countries where the discussion about membership is alive, such as Georgia and Moldova, a lot of fake news about the EU is  circulating. Often, the messages come from pro-Russian accounts or are at least further disseminated by these accounts.
This is no coincidence. Over the past three years, elections have been held in many European countries. And attempts have been made to influence these elections. A
t mentions 503 deliberate influence campaigns in 2024 alone. These include disinformation campaigns by foreign powers.

VRT NEWS collected fact checks on these types of anti-EU messages that are demonstrably false. We found about 60 examples that have been circulating since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine. But this is only a small fraction of the many fake stories about the EU that can be found online.

It is, of course, legitimate to criticise the EU, or to believe that the organisation behaves in a “dictatorial” manner and that your country should leave the EU. But this is not about legitimate criticism of the EU. It is about false and fabricated claims, which originate or are reinforced by pro-Russian circles in order to discredit the EU.
The aim is always to stir up polarisation in a country, in the hope of ultimately changing or weakening current policy and, for example, making it more pro-Russian or undermining support for Ukraine.
, spread across almost all social media platforms known in Europe.
There is no evidence whatsoever that the
or introducing a mandatory number of LGBTI+ people
, but how can you tell if something is true or false?

The false claims we found can be divided into four recurring themes: the EU as a warmonger, the EU as a censoring power, the EU interfering in all aspects of our private lives and consumer affairs, and the EU influencing our identity.
When it comes to war, for example,
has already been able to demonstrate that the EU does not seize your savings to invest in defence, contrary to what is being said online. In addition, false stories about
or
service are also circulating.
Fake news about
or
presents the EU as a controlling power that tries to censor its citizens.
But less spectacular stories, which affect citizens' private lives and consumer behaviour, are also circulating. For example,
demonstrated that the European Commission does not require Slovak millers to add worms to their flour. That was a rumour that was circulating. Earlier this year,
also demonstrated that Europe is not secretly putting ‘insects in your bread’.

The EU promoting Islam and migration, and a misrepresentation of EU policy on the LGBTI+ community: here too, fake news presents the EU as an institution that wants to change the identity of its citizens. For example,
demonstrated that the EU does not give Portugal 3 million euros for every mosque built, as claimed online.

The various topics may be trivial and easy to refute. But the aim is not for each of these claims to be believed. Through all these fake claims, an image emerges of the EU as a dictatorial power that leaves no room for freedom and should therefore be distrusted by everyone. And through repetition, the idea seeps in.

How can you tell whether a message about a particular EU initiative is fake news or simply someone who sincerely disagrees with the direction the EU is taking? The various European institutions launch thousands of initiatives every year. So it is not always easy immediately to discern what is real and what is not. These tips will help you some way ahead:
: does a message make you feel anxious or angry? Check the message. Fake news targets your emotions, because in that way it spreads faster.

: sometimes fake news can contain a core of truth. Perhaps certain European legislation does exist, but certain elements are exaggerated or the legislation is not presented entirely accurately. Consider the example of the so-called
. Gel nails are not banned, but
is.

: where does the news come from? By searching for the exact words from a message, you can often find other and earlier versions of the message. This gives you an idea of the type of accounts that are mainly sharing the news. Are these reliable accounts or not?
: is the news being reported in different places and also in the mainstream media? Does what you read there correspond to the message on social media?
: see if there are already fact checks on the subject. You can do this, for example, at the
or, in Flanders, at
: If the initiative really exists, you can find it on the

The 60 false claims approximately we have collected originated in many different ways. Some stories seem to pop up out of nowhere on social media, while others involve misinterpreting existing information or a bold statement by a politician.
However, it is striking that pro-Russian accounts eagerly spread these claims once they are online. We see this, for example, in the case of the
and
It is a well-known phenomenon of Russian propaganda: repetition works. We saw this recently with stories about
. Here, too, the aim was to undermine the president's legitimacy through a relentless stream of fake news.

Russian propaganda is now doing the same with the EU: every story is intended to undermine the legitimacy of the EU in the minds of its citizens (and the citizens of countries that want to become members).
: how a fake news network disrupts elections in Europe
The
has discovered that a Russian-funded network attempted to influence

The network promised money to anyone who would spread pro-Russian propaganda and fake news. Participants were trained to produce and disseminate messages on social media via platforms such as Facebook and TikTok. The aim was to damage Moldova's pro-EU party.

The BBC's undercover journalist was asked to write unfounded accusations. One example is the claim that Moldova's possible EU membership would depend on whether the country's citizens would ‘change their sexual orientation to LGBT’.

The internet is full of criticism of the EU and its rules. And that is fine if it is based on facts. But on social media, especially when elections in European countries are approaching, we see false messages popping up from pro-Russian circles. Based on lies and false information, they try to make people angry with the European Union.

Most stories are quickly debunked. But by promoting similar stories over and over again, something seeps into most people's minds. It is the tactic of repetition that Russian propaganda regularly uses. We see the same thing with stories about
By looking at the source of the reports and searching for other accounts of the news, you can find out whether or not it is fake news.

title: Broadcast worldwide but fake: video of explosion at Iran prison traced back to old photo
author: Rien Emmery
first_lines: A short video clip showing an explosion at Evin Prison in Tehran during an Israeli bombing raid is fake. The attack did take place, but the video in question – which has been widely broadcast and shared – is a fragment of an older photo of the prison gate. The photo was presumably edited into a moving image using AI technology.
content: News outlets around the world published images from a surveillance camera that allegedly captured the Israeli bombing of the notorious Evin Prison in the Iranian capital, Tehran, on 23 June.
However, an analysis by VRT’s fact-checking team shows that the images are fake: they are a fragment of a photo from January 2023, which has been edited into a video with an explosion added.
On Monday morning, 23 June, Israel announced that it had bombed several symbolic sites in Iran, including Evin Prison in the capital, Tehran.
The prison is notorious for the hundreds of dissidents and other political prisoners who are being held there. One of them is
, the Iranian-Swedish emergency doctor and visiting professor at the Vrije Universiteit Brussel who has been accused of espionage by the Iranian regime and sentenced to death.

The most spectacular image of the attack was a 6-second black-and-white clip showing an explosion at the prison gate. The images appear to be from a surveillance camera. They were shared on social media by Iranian journalists such as
, and by Israeli Foreign Minister
The footage was also picked up by news media around the world. It was featured in reports by
, CNN in the US, the British public broadcaster BBC and VTM-Journaal.
There is no doubt that Evin Prison in Tehran is shown at the beginning of the video. The sign and the barred windows are clearly recognisable in other photos of the building.
Using
, an image search engine, we performed a search using the opening image of the video. The result is a
of Evin Prison that bears a striking resemblance to the source material.
Further reverse image search queries reveal cropped versions of the same photo on various websites.
cites a Twitter profile as the source: @iaaraash.
On that profile, we indeed found the
of the gate of Evin Prison. The image appears to have been posted by Iranian citizen journalist Arash Hashemi more than two years ago, on 6 January 2023.

Image analysis showed that the first frame of the black-and-white footage apparently from the security camera fits perfectly into the larger colour photo from January 2023. You can see that first video image here in the red frame.
Further comparison also shows that the plants in the foreground of both images are identical.

Incidentally, this vegetation is another indication that the images of the explosion cannot be recent. The bare bushes correspond to the time when the photo was taken, in the winter month of January 2023, not to the situation in the summer month of June 2025.
An aerial photograph from June 2023, for example, shows how the bushes are normally in full leaf at this time of year.
Everything therefore points to the images in the video being fake. A section of an older, genuine photo of Evin Prison has been edited into a video with an explosion added.
This was probably done using an application based on AI. The phenomenon of adding explosions to images is quite common, to the extent that there are even
for it.
Although Evin Prison was indeed bombed on 23 June, these images are not authentic.
On Monday morning, 23 June, Israel bombed Evin Prison in the Iranian capital, Tehran.

A video appeared on social media showing surveillance camera footage of an explosion at the prison gate. Israeli government officials and Iranian media have shared the images, which have also been picked up by the world press.
However, the video is fake. A fragment of an older photo of Evin Prison, from January 2023, has been edited into a video showing an explosion. This was probably done using AI.
We therefore assess the viral video of the 23 June bombing of the prison to be false.
